105e0898cb9617a3e4beb644d3b1a46b (15:10): Kop`: That just shows you have never used it.

95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:10): I'm betting Linux, you can read in more text at a time than on Windows.
105e0898cb9617a3e4beb644d3b1a46b (15:10): And there is a HUGE diffrence.
95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:10): From a console applicationt hat is.

afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:11): What do you mean by "programmable"?
105e0898cb9617a3e4beb644d3b1a46b (15:11): With the huge amount of GNU tools that come with the standard GNU/Linux kernel and pipes and so on it becomes so powerfull.
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:12): oh well ok i guess
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:12): But it's not a limitation of command line applications
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:12): It's a limitation of tools you have available

95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:20): Kev, 32 bit supports like 2.5 GB of RAM
354f7f7909a41269f8e92e82c5ebc628 (15:20): here check out some native linux games with nice graphics :
95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:20): Yet Ubuntu 32 bit can support like 16 or something
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:21): 32bit Ubuntu supports 16 GB of RAM
105e0898cb9617a3e4beb644d3b1a46b (15:21): Koules is probibly one of my fav Linux games. It came with Slackware distro. Dont even know if that distro is still alive.
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:21): So pointers can only point to the first 4 GB
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:21): Since pointers are 32bit on a 32bit system
95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:21): Windows 32 bit doesn't even see past 2.5 GB
354f7f7909a41269f8e92e82c5ebc628 (15:21): Moose, I don't think that's true
c308c1360f81abe8baa690f77331d659 (15:21): Detecting X GB dosn't mean it can use it
abdaea7ed8da048add025c105955eaa4 (15:22): "Detecting" 8GB of memory doesn't mean individual applications on a 32-bit OS can address beyond 32-bits.
95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:22): reverseblade, Windows 32 bit only showing 2.5 or so?
abdaea7ed8da048add025c105955eaa4 (15:22): Jemt is right on the money.
354f7f7909a41269f8e92e82c5ebc628 (15:22): the whole point of 64 bit is passing beyond 4 gb
354f7f7909a41269f8e92e82c5ebc628 (15:22): Moose, I don't think 32 bit ubuntu can map more than 4 gb ram
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:22): The maximum address you can address with a 32 bit pointer is 2^32 = 4 gb
7d613c196198ffcd9319be9b582f1535 (15:22): Moose there's a configuration that allow you to use more than 2GB (ie up to 3GB)
95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:22): reverseblade, it detects it and Windows does not. I'm going with that as supporting.
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:22): So there's no way you can address past the 4 gb mark
354f7f7909a41269f8e92e82c5ebc628 (15:23): because the address bus is 32 bit in 32 bit cpu
95bc0fb3cf2e7665d0eecfad473b47c6 (15:23): Yes and did you not read what I said?
c308c1360f81abe8baa690f77331d659 (15:23): Moose: Again, detecting it is not the same as using it
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:23): He may be saying that it shows "8 gb" on the control panel or whatever
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:23): But that you can only use 4
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:23): And he calls that "supporting 8 gb"
afdc6209096af959bb8a52bdf7d5aa6d (15:23): It doesn't support 8 gb if you can't use it
354f7f7909a41269f8e92e82c5ebc628 (15:24): but still this is an advantage of linux compared to windows anyway
abdaea7ed8da048add025c105955eaa4 (15:24): reverseblade: His definition of "supporting" means the OS will at some point tell you that you have N amount of RAM.
7d613c196198ffcd9319be9b582f1535 (15:24): can't really use 4 anyway cause the system need some addressable space on its own
7d613c196198ffcd9319be9b582f1535 (15:24): that's why you can't have 4gb in winxp
c308c1360f81abe8baa690f77331d659 (15:24): He's not using the word "supporting" properly then
354f7f7909a41269f8e92e82c5ebc628 (15:24): anyway, linux rocks windows sucks, period
